Units.UnitGuidingQuestion:
Close reading of the unit texts will help you answer these Guiding Questions:

  1. What is a community?
  2. Why are communities important?
  3. Why are rules important to communities?
  4. How are the communities in our readings like our classroom community? How are they different?
Units.UnitOverview: In this unit, you will think about our classroom as a community, and through the readings learn how other communities function and how each community reflects the culture and the needs of its group members.

Episodes.Description: In this episode, you will complete a piece of writing to show what you already know about narratives. You will learn several routines that will be used in your class throughout this year. You also get to read the story, Boxes for Katje!

Lessons.LessonOverview: Today, you are going to learn about what makes a community a community. You will explore your device and you will find out what you will be doing in class every day.
Today, you will see what books are available for you to select for daily Independent Reading. You will also be setting some reading goals for yourself for this year.
Today, you are going to review genres and find out what the expectations are for you as a third grader.
Today, you will work with your classmates to develop a rubric for Independent Reading.
Today, you and your classmates will show what you already know about narrative writing by taking a quick assessment.
Today, you will learn about the Common Read. Get ready to start your first Common Read!
You have already discussed the community you live in and the community of readers in your classroom. Today, you will discuss the two communities that are in Boxes for Katje.
Today, you will learn another element of strong narrative writing: temporal words. You will reread selected pages from Boxes for Katje and then, as a class, you will find temporal words in the text.

Authors choose specific words to communicate meaning. You and your classmates will discuss word choice in Boxes for Katje. Your teacher will also explain what a Reading Conference is and how to have one in your class.

Episodes.Description: You focus in this episode on informational texts, and read the book What is a Community? from A to Z. You explore the meaning of community, and start to work on your class project—interviewing and reporting on a member of your school community.

Lessons.LessonOverview: Today, you and your classmates will write an informational piece to show how much you already know about writing informational texts.
Today, you will build on what you already know about communities. You will also start reading a new book—What is a Community? from A to Z.

Have you ever heard someone say “two heads are better than one”? It means it is easier for two people to solve a problem than it is for one person alone. Today, you will work with a partner during reading and find out how two heads are better than one.

Today, you will discuss just what makes your school a community. You will identify and write about the big ideas in your reading. You will choose a member of your school community to interview, and brainstorm some questions to ask that person about his or her role in the school community.

Today, you will learn about the parts of an email, and you will write a message to the community member you selected. You will begin to draft your report, and ask your partner for feedback on what you have written.
Today, you will be introduced to Writing Conferences—a great way to learn how to become a better writer. You will work on writing your report, and you will learn some new vocabulary words.
In this lesson, you will learn how conjunctions can help make meaning clearer in your writing. You will also help create a list of revision strategies. Then you will revise your report.
In this lesson, you will make a list of the spelling strategies you can use. Some of them may be review and some will be new. All of them will be helpful.
Your report is almost complete. You know what your piece says and what it means, but will it make sense to the reader? Today, you are going to learn about editing.
Today, you will learn about Response Groups. You will participate in a Response Group, giving feedback to and receiving feedback from your group members.
Today you will finish your interview report on your chosen community member and then share with a partner. You will also reflect on the importance of school community members.

Episodes.Description: In Episode 3, you refresh your opinion-writing skills. You get to learn about chimpanzees in the wild to help you further explore the concept of community. You also get to read two articles: “Watching in the Wild” and “Pet Primates: Why Not?” You will learn more class routines, including Guided Reading and Book Clubs.

Lessons.LessonOverview: Today, you will show how much you already know about writing an effective opinion essay.
Today you will watch a short video called Mammals: Chimp Tools and read the rest of "Watching in the Wild." You will also learn some new vocabulary words.
Today, you will read an example of opinion writing called “Pet Primates: Why Not?” You will also play a game called “So You Want to Be a Millionaire?”

Today, you will review the elements of a strong opinion piece as you get ready to write your own opinion piece. Then you will write your opinion piece using the Common Read and the videos you watched.
Today, you will meet in Response Groups to read your writing. You will give each other some suggestions to make the ideas in your writing clear and interesting.
Today, you will learn what a Guided Reading Group is and how you will be working in one to help your reading skills grow stronger. You will also write another opinion piece and take a poll.
Today, one Guided Reading Group will demonstrate what a Guided Reading session looks like. You will also have time to revise the opinion piece you wrote in the last lesson.
Today, you will learn what a Book Club is and you will get to choose a few books that you would like to read in a Book Club. You will also finish your revisions of your opinion piece.

Today, you are going to explore Book Clubs some more. You will watch as your teacher and classmates demonstrate a Book Club meeting. Then you will prepare for your own Book Club meeting by reading one of the three books you have selected.

This is the final lesson in this unit. Today, you will do some thinking about what you have learned. You will start with vocabulary work, then reflect on your reading goals and set new ones. Finally, you will participate in your first Book Club discussion!

Units.UnitGuidingQuestion:
Close reading of the texts in this unit will help you answer these Guiding Questions:

  • What is your personal responsibility to the class community and to the other communities to which you belong?
  • If you could make all the class, family, or town rules by yourself, what would they be?
  • How can words of wisdom make our communities better?
Units.UnitOverview: In exploring community membership and its privileges and responsibilities, you will learn that individuals can make a difference, and that they have the power to change things for the better in their communities.

Episodes.Description: In this episode, you will learn about the rights and responsibilities of belonging to a community. You will explore community membership through narrative text, focusing on the school community. You will learn that community members can change a community.

Lessons.LessonOverview: In this lesson, you will review what you know about communities. You will learn some new vocabulary words. You will also begin to read Birdsong for Anna.
Today, you will learn how authors develop characters in a story. You will also learn how your feelings can help you understand a character in a story. You will add to your vocabulary words.

Today, you will learn how illustrations help a reader understand a story. You will study how Anna’s character changes over time, and you will continue to reflect on how your actions affect others in a community. You will also learn why the verbs in a sentence always agree with their subjects.
Today, you will practice writing Gists and explore the author’s purpose, or big idea, in Birdsong for Anna. You will also review your vocabulary words.
Today, you will connect your personal experience to the text you are reading. You will also practice using a dictionary and a rubric.
Today, you will discuss Birdsong for Anna. You will continue to practice new vocabulary words. You will learn what a memoir is, and you will use a narrative map to chart the events in a story.
Today, you will practice annotating a text as you read. Then you will begin to work on a memoir of your own! You will learn to use the narrative map to help you write your memoir.

In this lesson, you will revise your memoir using the Grade 3 Narrative Writing Rubric and feedback from your Response Group. You will also study pronouns, deconstruct sentences, and learn some new vocabulary words.
Today, you will review some useful strategies to help you make final revisions to your memoir. You will also meet with your Book Club and practice writing a Gist.
Today, you will review some useful editing strategies to help you polish your memoir, and then you will submit your final draft. You will also read and review some of your classmates’ memoirs.

Episodes.Description: In this episode, students will learn that every community member has a unique point of view that affects how he or she acts and thinks. They will use poetry to explore their opinions about community. They will consider their own perspective as they write and revise a poem about community.

Lessons.LessonOverview: Today, you will look at another form of writing—a poem. It is called “If I Were in Charge of the World,” and it was written by Judith Viorst. You will compare the poem with a narrative story, and then you will help to write a class poem. You will also learn some new vocabulary words.

Today, you will rehearse and perform a poem with your group. You will study compound words and learn some new vocabulary words. You will also explore how colors can connect to the mood of what you are reading.

Today, you will write and revise your own “If I Were in Charge” poem. You will learn why revision is such an important part of writing, and you will learn some good strategies to help you revise your work. You will also work with pronouns and antecedents, and you will learn some new vocabulary words.

Today, you will perform your poem with your group in the classroom “poetry café.” Then you will work on a new group poem about your school. You will record your poem and add photos to your presentation.

Episodes.Description: In this episode, you will explore community responsibility and service. You will read and compare two texts about community service and learn how some individuals gave back to their communities. You will also compare how each unit text portrays community responsibility.

Lessons.LessonOverview: Today, you will think about the different communities you belong to. You will read a new informational text called Serving Your Community by Christin Ditchfield. You will also learn about choosing the right dictionary definition when a word has more than one.

Today, you will watch a video of President John F. Kennedy’s famous speech about helping others. You will continue reading Serving Your Community by Christin Ditchfield, and you will write a Gist about the big idea in this text.
Today, you will explore how and why people volunteer to help their communities. You will practice note taking and learn how to use two new graphic organizers to help you take notes while you read.

Today, you will discuss how a big disaster such as a hurricane can affect a community and how people can work together to help. You will compare the two informational texts you have read and make connections between them. You will learn how to identify important events and how writers use the “five Ws” when they report information.
In this lesson, you will write, revise, and edit a news report about something that happened in your class or school. Then you will work with a partner to make a video newscast of your report.

Episodes.Description: In this episode, you will explore a photo essay showing how people from around the world share words of wisdom. You will discuss how communities use life lessons and words of wisdom to share values. You will craft your own words of wisdom and use them to create a photo essay.

Lessons.LessonOverview: Today, you will read a new text, Wise at Heart. You will learn about words of wisdom and come up with your own words of wisdom. You will also make connections between the texts you have read so far.

Today, you will begin your photo-essay project. First, you will review the text Wise at Heart with your class, looking carefully at the content, structure, and features of this text. Then you will discuss ideas for your class photo-essay and work on writing your own words of wisdom for the project.

Today, you will continue to work on your words of wisdom photo-essay. You will work with partners and your teacher to revise and edit your writing. You will choose a location for your photo that goes with your essay, and you will work with a partner to take the photo.

Today, you will complete your words of wisdom photo-essay. You will take a class photo to help you remember how this community has worked together. Then you will share your photo-essay with your group.

In this lesson, you will discuss how to put words of wisdom into action. You will practice annotating a page from Wise at Heart, and you will conclude your Book Club meetings. You will reflect on the Guiding Questions for this unit.
Today, you will work on your Portfolio. First, you will review the writing you have already saved in your Portfolio. Then you will write a new piece to add to your Portfolio.

Units.UnitGuidingQuestion:
"If we did all the things we were capable of doing, we would literally astound ourselves."

--Thomas Edison
Units.UnitOverview: In this unit, you will use all that you have learned about informational text features to comprehend new informational texts and to write a report on animal adaptations.

Lessons.LessonOverview: Today, you will build background knowledge about the importance of animal adaptations to their survival.
Today, you will read for information about animals, their habitats, and their physical and behavioral adaptations.
Today, you will continue reading about animals and their physical and/or behavioral adaptations.
Over the next two lessons, you will complete the culminating assessment for this unit. You’ll read text and answer questions that will reflect your reading comprehension.
In this lesson, you will take the writing portion of the culminating assessment. You will continue to use the skills you have learned in the first three lessons of this unit.

Units.UnitGuidingQuestion:
Close reading of the unit texts will help you answer these Guiding Questions.

  • What are the features of narrative writing?
  • What strategies and vocabulary do narrative writers use to create texts that are well-organized and engaging to the reader?
Units.UnitOverview: In this five-lesson unit, you will learn ways to improve your skills in narrative writing.

Lessons.LessonOverview:
We all enjoy reading a great story. But what makes a great story? What are the features of great stories?

Stories (fictional or autobiographical writing) are called narratives. In this unit, you will learn to write engaging and well-organized narratives.

You will explore the features of narrative writing and learn how to include them in your own work.
In today’s lesson, you will learn how to write strong and engaging introductions. You will revise the introductions to your Cold Write based on what you learn.

In this lesson, you will learn how narratives are organized, and you will revise the events in your narrative to create a well-organized sequence.

You will also learn how to use words and phrases to give your reader clues about how your narrative is moving in time.

Today, you will learn how to develop your narratives to make them more detailed and engaging by 1) describing main characters’ actions, thoughts, and feelings, and 2) using purposeful dialogue.

You will use what you learn to revise your Cold Write.

Today, you will learn how to create closure (an ending) in your narrative. You will revise the endings of your Cold Writes.

You will also have time to make additional revisions and edits to your Cold Write narratives, and then you will share your work with a small group.

Units.UnitGuidingQuestion:
Close reading of the texts in this unit will help you answer these Guiding Questions:

  • Why are stories important to communities?
  • What can we learn from fictional stories?
  • What can stories teach us about the people who tell them?
Units.UnitOverview: You will consider how the values and expectations of a community are often reflected in the stories they tell. The stories in this unit teach about right and wrong and help shape the character of the community members.

Episodes.Description: In Episode 1, you will discuss four stories from around the world. You will find similarities that cultures share and differences that make each culture unique. You will learn storytelling techniques and create stories that include elements of your culture and community.

Lessons.LessonOverview: Today, you will read the book Crow Boy by Taro Yashima. You will learn how an author sets the tone, or mood, of a story. You will practice retelling a story and compare the plots of two stories. You will also look at different ways that communities solve problems.

Today, you will learn about theme. You will write a Gist about the theme that is shared by Crow Boy and Birdsong for Anna. You also will write an opinion piece about the story you liked best and prepare to meet with your new Book Club.

In this lesson, you will read Chicken Sunday by Patricia Polacco. You will see what you can learn about community from this author and study some new vocabulary words. Then you will think about how this author and others can inspire you as a writer.

Today, you will discuss Chicken Sunday with your classmates. You can learn a lot by discussing a text with others. You will also begin writing a new fiction story of your own and meet with your new Book Club.
Today, you have a special treat! You are going to watch a professional storyteller in action. You will hear a special type of story called a pourquoi tale.

“Pourquoi” is the French word for “why.” Today, you will read a pourquoi tale called “Grandmother Spider Steals the Sun.” Then you will use what you have learned about storytelling to tell your own story.
Today, you will edit and polish your realistic fiction story to get it ready to share. You will also practice your rephrasing skills on Chicken Sunday.

Often an author tries to tell you something important in his or her writing. Today, you will learn how to determine what the author’s message is. You will write an opinion piece about one of the texts you have read so far in this unit. You will also learn how storytellers give clues about their community and culture, and do more storytelling of your own.

Now that you know how to find the author’s message, you are going to find the message in Chicken Sunday and in your Book Club book. You will also review and revise your opinion piece with help from your Response Group.

You have been working like a detective to find clues to the author’s message in your texts. Today, you will find the clues about community in your Independent Reading book. You will edit your opinion piece for Author’s Chair. Then you will wrap up your storytelling practice by video recording your finished story.

Today, you will return to one of the unit texts to find clues about community and culture. Then you will share your findings. You will also have a chance to see how you have grown as a storyteller as you compare your stories with those of your classmates.

Episodes.Description: In Episode 2, you will look closely at different versions of the Cinderella story from around the world. You will notice how certain ideas show up in communities around the world and see how cultural norms are reflected in the stories. Then you will write your own Cinderella story.

Lessons.LessonOverview: Today, you will start by reading a version of a familiar story, Cinderella. You will look at how the ideas in stories you already know can inspire your own writing.
Today, you will finish reading Cinderella and discuss the book with your classmates. Then you will write a Gist about the big idea in this story and share it.

In this lesson, you will read another Cinderella story, The Rough-Face Girl by Rafe Martin. You will practice rephrasing and fluency skills. You will also make a graffiti board to share your ideas about community.

Today, you will read a Cinderella tale called Mufaro’s Beautiful Daughters by John Steptoe. You will practice retelling this story with a group. Then, you will think about what the Cinderella story would be like if it took place in your community, in the present day. You will begin writing your own version of the story.

In this lesson, your group will discuss why the same story is told in so many different cultures. You will also continue to work on writing your Cinderella story. Today, you will focus on choosing the words to describe the setting of your story.

Today, you will revisit the big ideas found in the unit texts you have read so far. What do you notice about these ideas? You are also going to work on revising your Cinderella story, and practice reading aloud with fluency.
As you are reading today, you will look for clues about community and culture in your Independent Reading book. Then you will work on editing your Cinderella story.

Today, you will think about why the same big ideas appear in books from so many different places. You will add a title and some illustrations to your Cinderella story. Then you will publish your story!

Today, you will review all of the books you have read in this unit and choose a favorite book to write about. You will read some of the Cinderella stories your classmates wrote, and give the writers your feedback.

Today, you will meet with a Response Group to get feedback on your opinion piece. Then you will make your final revisions and practice reading your piece aloud. You are getting ready to make a recording! You will also reflect on the writing you have done in this unit and discuss the Guiding Questions with your class.

Episodes.Description: In Episode 3, you will choose, read, and discuss Book Club selections. You will also complete a series of Benchmark Assessments (Cold Writes). Then you will reflect on your reading and writing as you choose your favorite pieces and write opinions for your portfolio.

Lessons.LessonOverview: Today, you and your classmates will show what you know about narrative writing by taking a quick assessment.
Today, you and your classmates will write an informational piece to show how much you know about writing informational texts.
A penny for your thoughts! Today, you will show how much you know about writing an effective opinion piece.
Today, you will reflect on your growth as a reader and a writer. You will record yourself reading a story and you will choose your best writing from the unit to put in your portfolio.

Units.UnitGuidingQuestion:
Close reading of the unit texts will help you answer these Guiding Questions:

  1. What are the features of informational writing?
  2. What kinds of information do writers use to make their texts interesting and reliable?
Units.UnitOverview: In this five-lesson unit, you will learn ways to improve your skills in informational writing.

Lessons.LessonOverview: Writing a good informational report is fun and an important skill to learn! In this lesson, you will think about the features of informational writing and begin to revise your informational report on the animal you selected.
Today, you will learn more about informational writing. Then you will start writing the introduction to your animal report.
Today, you will continue to work on your animal report.
Today, you will look at three important features of your report. You will learn about linking words to use in your report, and you will decide how you will write your conclusion.
Today, you will share your animal report with some of your classmates!

Units.UnitGuidingQuestion:
Close reading of the texts in this unit will help you answer these Guiding Questions:

  • Why do authors use animals as characters?
  • What can humans learn by studying animals and their behavior?
  • Animals, both wild and domestic, are part of our communities. What responsibility do humans have for animals?
Units.UnitOverview: You will study animal characteristics in fiction as well as nonfiction, exploring animal roles in different stories and communities and the ways we can learn from animals in stories to make our own lives better.

Episodes.Description: In the first episode, you will explore narratives with animals. You will read Hallie Leaves Home by Sheila Sweeny Higginson and learn that there’s no place like home. You will also read fables that use animal characters to teach a lesson.

Lessons.LessonOverview: In this lesson, you will explore the characteristics of animal communities and learn how human and animal communities can be similar. You will create a chart to list the different characteristics, and you will start reading the fable “King Lion and the Beetle.”

In this lesson, you will read another fable, called “The Hen and the Apple Tree.” You will continue to explore why authors write fables and why authors use animals as characters in their stories and fables.

In this lesson, you will reread two fables and then complete character profiles with the class, listing the traits of the characters in the stories. Then you will think of your own idea for a fable that you will write, and you will create a Character Profile chart for your fable.

Today, you will read a new story called Hallie Leaves Home. Your teacher will show you how to sequence the events in a fable. You will also learn how to use the Tell Me What You Think Form for book rating.
Today, you will plan a storyline for your own fable. Then you will read the second chapter of Hallie Leaves Home and annotate the text.

In this lesson, you will further explore the tools authors use to give their characters attributes. Then you will read the third chapter in Hallie Leaves Home and discuss possible morals for the story.

In this lesson, you will learn why word choice is so important when writing a fable. You will watch your teacher model writing a fable using a character profile, storyline, and moral or lesson. Then you will continue to work on your own fable.

In this lesson, you will watch a video of Jerry Pinkney discussing the fable “The Lion and the Mouse.” You will discuss why fables are important to communities. Then you will work with the class to construct a closing for your teacher’s fable, and you will revise your own fable.

Episodes.Description: Episode 2 will ask you to think about an animal you are interested in and create an informational poster about that animal.

Lessons.LessonOverview: Today, you will learn how to use symbols, or codes, to mark up what you are reading. You will read a text called “A Day for Tigers,” and you will also begin to read The Tale of Despereaux.
Today, you will learn about text features and how they can help you understand what you are reading. You will also continue to research your animal of choice and read The Tale of Despereaux.

Today, you will learn about what text structures are and how authors use them to communicate clearly with their readers. You will also continue to research your chosen animal for the poster project, and you will read a new text called Turtles & Tortoises. You will also continue to read The Tale of Despereaux.

Today, you will view information about extinct animals and discuss the major problems animals can have in a community. You will learn the different ways authors organize information, and you will start to organize the information you gathered for your poster.
Today, you will review Turtles & Tortoises to look for examples of text structure. Then you will begin to draft your poster, and you will continue to read The Tale of Despereaux.
Today, you will read a new text called “Wild or Wrangled.” You will use coding strategies to mark up the article and discuss your thinking, and then you will continue to work on your poster.
Today, you will learn how authors use correct and dependable information in what they write. You will also learn some new grammar skills and continue to work on your poster project.
Today, you will learn about horse roundups in the American West. You will also finish your informational poster and continue to read The Tale of Despereaux.
Today, you will review and evaluate your partner’s poster. Then you will go on a Gallery Walk to view your classmates’ posters.

Episodes.Description: In Episode 3, you will learn how stories can use animals to teach us about human behavior and relationships. You will use The Tale of Despereaux to discover what these fictional animals can teach us about our lives.

Lessons.LessonOverview: Today, you will watch a video about rescued animals. Then you will read an article about a rescued turtle and discuss it with the class. You will also read The Tale of Despereaux.
Today, you will learn how to spot the main ideas in an informational article. You will also learn more about how animals can help humans.
Today, you will review the rubric for opinion writing and watch as the teacher points out the key features of an opinion piece.

Today, you will continue to explore the themes of The Tale of Despereaux with your teacher, and you will learn how to use a rubric to organize an opinion piece. You will then draft an opinion piece of your own.
Today, you will continue to work on your opinion piece.
Today, you will read some of your classmates’ writing and then discuss what they wrote with the class. You will also improve an example and then practice writing your own opinion piece.
Today, you will edit your opinion piece.
Today, you will finish writing your opinion piece, and then you will share it with the class. You will review and make decisions about the contents of your portfolio.

Units.UnitGuidingQuestion:
"I'm not afraid of storms, for I am learning how to sail my ship."
― Louisa May Alcott, Little Women
Units.UnitOverview: In this unit, you will apply what you’ve learned in previous texts and units to demonstrate your ability to comprehend poetry, take notes on and interpret themes, memorize a poem, write your opinion of a poem, and reflect on your writing.

Lessons.LessonOverview: In today’s lesson, you will read and study two poems about sleep and bedtime.
Today, you will read another poem and learn how poets sometimes talk about the everyday things you experience.
Today, you will perform your choral reading and compare the themes of two of Stevenson’s poems. Then you will read one more of his poems.
Over the next two lessons, you will complete the culminating assessment for this unit. You will read text and answer questions that will reflect your reading comprehension.
In this lesson, you will take the writing portion of the culminating assessment. You will continue to use the skills you have learned in the first three lessons of this unit.

Units.UnitGuidingQuestion:
Close reading of the unit texts will help you answer these Guiding Questions:

  1. What is opinion writing?
  2. What are the features of opinion writing?
  3. What strategies do writers use to write a strong opinion piece?
Units.UnitOverview: In this five-lesson unit, you will learn ways to improve your skills in opinion writing.

Lessons.LessonOverview:
Writing a good opinion piece is fun, and it’s an important skill for you to learn. In this lesson, you will learn how writers write strong opinion pieces on a topic by creating a powerful introduction.

You will learn how to introduce the topic you are writing about by stating your opinion.
In this lesson, you will learn how writers create strong opinion pieces on a topic by supporting their points of view with reasons.
In this lesson, you will learn how writers explain their reasons with sufficient details. Also, you will learn how to use linking words and phrases to connect your opinion and reasons.
In this lesson, you will observe how writers develop a concluding statement. You will revise your writing to include a powerful conclusion.
In this lesson, you will proofread your opinion piece and then edit your work. Then, you will celebrate your work by sharing it with some of your classmates.

Units.UnitGuidingQuestion:
Close reading of the texts in this unit will help you answer these Guiding Questions:

  • What does it mean to “find your voice?”
  • Can an individual’s voice (yours for example!) make a difference in your community? How?
  • What is the cost of not “finding your voice?”
Units.UnitOverview: In this unit, you will learn what it means to find your voice and to speak up on issues that matter to you. You will examine respectful ways to stand up for rights and to solve problems – ways in which your voice can make a difference at school, at home, and in the world.

Episodes.Description: In this episode, you will examine respectful ways to stand up for community rights, share your views appropriately, and problem solve together. You will explore literary texts to see how authors reveal ways community members can use their voices to make a difference. In this episode, you will revisit the informational animal poster you created in Unit 4 and identify a way you can use your voice to make a difference for that animal.

Lessons.LessonOverview: Today, you will think about The Tale of Despereaux and the meaning of light and darkness in the story. You will also read independently and share your unit goals with the class.
Today, you will consider how “unlikely heroes” can make a difference. You will think about how Despereaux found his courage and how you might create positive change in your school or community.

In this lesson, you will read the story 14 Cows for America by Carmen Agra Deedy. You will reflect on ways to use your own voice to make a difference, and you will begin a project about an Animal Challenge that is important to you.
In this lesson, you will continue to think about when and how to use your voice within your community. You will also practice your annotation skills as you continue to reflect on 14 Cows for America.

In this lesson, you will explore the important ideas from the stories you have read so far. You will also continue to learn about the Animal Challenge you have chosen and discuss the project with a small group.
In this lesson, you will write a summary of 14 Cows for America. You will also review the information you have gathered so far about the Animal Challenge you chose and begin writing about it.
In this lesson, you will prepare to submit your Animal Challenge information project. You’ll also write about the importance of your voice in the community and exchange ideas with your classmates.
In this lesson, you will make sure your presentation is complete and update your teacher on your progress.

Episodes.Description: In this episode, you will think about why people speak up about problems in their communities. You will read about characters who speak up about things that are important to them, and you will write an opinion piece explaining an issue that is important to you. You will present your ideas to the class.

Lessons.LessonOverview: In this lesson, you will begin thinking about an opinion piece that you will write on an issue that is important to your community. You will also have a chance to review your classmates’ Animal Challenge information projects.
Today, you will examine a piece of opinion writing and learn different ways to support a reason. You will review the Grade 3 Opinion Writing Rubric and apply your new ideas to your own writing.

Today, you will sharpen your reading skills by focusing on an article about immigration. Your teacher will share some background information with you, and you will think about how the people in the article used their voices to change their community.

In this lesson, you will build on the skills from the previous lesson to understand the difference between the author’s point of view and your own. You will also continue working on your opinion writing piece.
In this lesson, you will read the story Marvelous Mattie and practice inferring the meaning of unfamiliar words. You will share your ideas with a partner and with the whole class.

In this lesson, you will learn about central ideas, using Marvelous Mattie as an example. Then you will work with a partner to find the story’s supporting details. You will also continue working on your opinion writing piece.
In this lesson, you will prepare to deliver your presentation and turn in your opinion writing piece. You’ll also reflect in writing on the people and characters you have read about in this unit.
It is time for your presentation! You will give your presentation and listen as your classmates share their opinion writing. You will also have a chance to reflect on the presentations.

Episodes.EpisodeName: Meeting People Who Found Their Voice
Episodes.Description: In this episode, you will get to know two people who found their voices. You will do this by reading and studying the genre of biography. You will also write a biography of a family member.

Lessons.LessonOverview: In this lesson, you will learn about a woman who found her voice and became a Supreme Court justice. You will also launch into a study of the genre of biography and make plans to write a biography of an adult family member.
In this lesson, you will study the text Sonia Sotomayor to “read as a writer.” You will learn how to use a timeline and develop questions for interviewing the family member you plan to write about.

In this lesson, you will orally retell the biography of Sonia Sotomayor and determine the main idea of the text. You will continue to study sentence deconstruction and begin to draft your family member biography.
In this lesson, you will annotate Sonia Sotomayor by reading as a writer. You will also continue to write the biography of your chosen subject.

In this lesson, you will write and talk about the DREAM Act and Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor. You will read like a writer to study how to conclude a biography. You will continue to work on your biography.

In this lesson, you will learn about and discuss how women’s lives changed between the time Margaret E. Knight was born and the time Sonia Sotomayor was born. You will also meet in response groups to solicit feedback on your biography before revising your work.
In this lesson, you will read the biography of a famous baseball player, Roberto Clemente. You will hone your Gist-writing skills and edit your biography.

In this lesson, you will recount key details in the biography of Roberto Clemente and explain how they support the main idea. You will practice reading for fluency, and you will polish your biography.
In this lesson, you will compare and contrast the two biographies written by the same author, Jonah Winter. You will bring your portfolio up to date.

Units.UnitDescription: In this project unit, we will work together to make a real and positive change in our school community. We will identify an issue and then work in groups to organize, act, and assess the result.
Units.UnitGuidingQuestion:
Close reading of the texts in this unit will help you answer these Guiding Questions:

  • Who should have a say in what should be done to improve something in a community?
  • Why is it important for individuals to do what they can to improve their community?
  • How do you know when you have improved something in your community?
  • Can one individual or group really improve things in a community? Why or why not?
Units.UnitOverview: In this project unit, you will work together with your class to make a real and positive change in your school community. You will identify an issue and then work in groups to organize, act, and assess the result.

Episodes.Description: Episode 1 begins with a story about a fictional class that launches a volunteer project. Then, you and your class will identify a problem, issue, or challenge in the school community and plan a project together. Using your own observations and documentation, as well as outreach to the community, your class will choose one thing to work on, to make life better for the people in your community.

Lessons.LessonOverview: In this lesson, you will read a text, Mr. Post’s Project, about a class that starts a volunteer project at its school. You will then learn about a project you will do that will give you the chance to explore your own school community and learn more about it.
In this lesson, you will retell the story of Mr. Post’s Project. You will also write a rephrasing of the story and a Gist.
In this lesson, you will look closely at how the author of Mr. Post’s Project uses dialogue.
In this lesson, you will learn more about this unit’s community project. You will explore and document the different places in your school community and the things that happen there.
Today, you will use the information that you gathered to write a profile of one of the places in your school.
In this lesson, you will write captions for the photographs that you took in Lesson 4. You will also play a game with photo captions!
Today, you will learn all about blogs, and then with your group you will start your own blog!

In this lesson, you will use information gathered during your exploration to identify things in your community that you might focus on for your project. You will also create a survey to learn what other members of your community think the school community can do better.
Today, you will distribute the surveys to community members and make plans for how to encourage people to complete and return the surveys.
In this lesson, you will work with your project group to plan a presentation that you will present to other groups about the work you have done on your project to date.
Today you will look closely at all of the data from your survey of the community.
Today is election day! Vote to select one problem or issue in your school community that you will work to change.

Episodes.Description: Once your class has identified the issue, you will begin Episode 2, in which you research all facets of the problem, clearly define your goal (vision), and make specific action plans to work toward that goal. Then, you will work in small groups to follow through on your action plans.

Lessons.LessonOverview: In this lesson, you will consider your chosen project in greater detail.
In this lesson, you will continue with your research. Different groups may be at different points in their research and that is OK.
In this lesson, you will write an opinion piece to gather support from the school community for the change you want to make.
In this lesson, you will begin making specific plans that will lead to the change you want for your school community.

In this lesson, you will work on your project. Each group may be doing something different from the other groups. For example, you may be updating your blog, or revising your work plan, or meeting with the teacher while another group is working on something else.
In this lesson, you will learn about other people who have worked to change their school community. You may find their work to be an inspiration for your own project.
Today, you and your classmates will show what you know about narrative writing by taking a quick assessment.
Today, you and your classmates will write an informational piece to show how much you know about writing informational texts.

Episodes.EpisodeName: Present and Reflect on Your Project
Episodes.Description: In Episode 3, you reflect on your work and the impact your project had on the school community. You will also plan and deliver a presentation to an audience of people from outside the class. Then you and your classmates will put the finishing touches on your portfolios.

Lessons.LessonOverview: A penny for your thoughts! Today, you will show how much you know about writing an effective opinion piece. You will also begin to put the finishing touches on your third grade portfolio.
In this lesson, you will continue to work on your portfolio and reflect on the work you have done on this project. You will turn the focus on yourself and what you were able to accomplish.
In this lesson, you will continue to work on your portfolio. Then you will plan your final project presentation. The whole class will work together to deliver the presentation.
In this lesson, you will continue to work on your portfolio and prepare for your final presentation.
In this lesson, you will showcase your portfolio. Then you will deliver your final presentation to an audience!
